name: Baked Spring Rolls
headline: Baked Spring Rolls
keywords: Healthy Dinner,Healthy,Healthy Lunch,Lunch,Asian Appetizer,Appetizer,Asian,Sauce Recipes,Carrot Recipes,Crab Recipes,Shellfish Recipes,Cabbage Recipes,Ham,Low-Cholesterol,Heart-Healthy,Low-Carb,Low Calorie,Diabetes-Friendly,Low-Fat,Recipes for Parties,Recipes for a Crowd
recipeIngredient: 4 teaspoons vegetable oil, plus more for brushing

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees. Make the spring rolls: Cook the ham in 2 teaspoons vegetable oil in a small nonstick skillet over medium heat until crisp, 2 to 4 minutes. Add the ginger, garlic and scallions; cook until fragrant, about 1 more minute.
Toss the cabbage and carrot with the hot ham mixture in a large bowl. Add the crab, cilantro, chili-garlic paste, 1 teaspoon sesame oil, the soy sauce and vinegar; toss.
Wrap the spring rolls (see right). Pierce each roll with a skewer in a few places to prevent bursting.

Place a rack in a baking dish and brush with vegetable oil. Mix the remaining 2 teaspoons vegetable oil and 1/2 teaspoon sesame oil; lightly brush on rolls. Place the rolls on the rack; bake until golden on top, about 15 minutes. Turn the rolls; bake until golden and crisp, 8 to 10 more minutes.
Meanwhile, mix all the sauce ingredients in a small bowl. Serve with the warm spring rolls.

review.reviewBody: Made it today. Looks fantastic.  I usually used to fry not deep fry and all the fillings will fall out . Now I have intact crunchy baked spring rolls, yay! Thank you for sharing.
I think it's a typo with regards to the "Spring roll", I think it supposed to be an "egg roll" ingredient. But tasty otherwise.

These were great for baked rolls. I loved how crisp they were I didn't have a rack to put above the baking dish so I just put a cookie sheet under the existing bakers rack and sprayed the rack with olive oil. I used the egg white to seal the edge but also at the end adding the oil to brush i combined that with the egg white and brushed the oil and egg white on the rolls and they turned out beautiful! It's helpful in rolling to have the squares positioned like a diamond in front of you, put the filling in the middle and fold the diamond in half tuck in the sides and roll. There weren't instructions that I could see on that so thought I'd add say what I did! If I make them again i would do more veggies and less meat.

These were very good and in a weird way fun to make. I used a pre mixed store bought bag of coleslaw and I used chicken, no crabmeat nor ham.  My only complaint would be and its probably my oven it took lot longer for my rolls to get golden brown and secondly now I have all these asian ingredients I had to buy so now I need ideas what to do with it all :o).
Fantastic.  I do prefer to have one protein so it can be the star. BTW, the egg white is brushed on the roll just before closing to seal the roll completely.

we made these using the broccoli slaw. we put shrimp and crab in the mix. I also cooked the broccoli slaw a little bit to sweat it down. they were great. we bought some plumb dip for them. I also wonder where the egg is supposed to go. o well we will do these again soon.
I made these but wondered were does the 1 egg white go?

Made these for dinner last night and loved them!  We didn't have crab so we substituted shrimp in it's place, but other than that we follwed the recipe exactly.  This recipe will be a keeper in our home. :)
egg whites
Ham?? Are you kidding me??? Has to be a typo....sounds disgusting with the ham, perhaps doable without it.
I made these for the second time this weekend and followed the advice of other reviewers & used the broccoli slaw.  I don't use the ham, just crabmeat, and again these were a huge hit!

These were great! I read the other reviews and saw that several people said that the skin got hard from baking. To prevent that, right after you take the rolls out of the oven, cover them with wet paper towels for about a minute. This steams them but still keeps them crispy! I could not tell a difference between these and the fried version. I also substituted chicken for the crab because I'm allergic to shellfish, and they were still amazing! Definitely a do-over!

Great dish with great flavor. I always omit the ham and kick up the spice level. The shells do get a little tough in the oven, but not in a bad way; just different from when they're deep fried. Honestly, I love them cold out of the fridge.
To LITH 52, probably added up all the ingredients by nutriional info provided by W.W. and divided by the number of servings.  2 Points is pretty low, Zero being the lowest.

I love this recipe! I was looking for an appetizer for my 40th birthday bash, and this was a HIT!  I substituted shrimp for the ham ( I have friends who don't eat ham).....and it worked out perfectly. I bought prechopped cabbage/carrot mix, and threw it in the processor just two pulses smaller; it worked like a charm!  Baking them makes it such a healthier alternative. They turn out crispy and they were all gone in minutes. To save on time, I substituted prepared spring roll sauce. Drizzled that on the platter and they plated beautifully. Try them.....easy, tastey and impressive with little work.

I was so excited to see this great-sounding recipe, (and ones in other categories, too) but my NEW  healthy rule is that if there isn't a nutrition listing on a recipe, I no longer try them or save them.  There's not time to figure it out ingredient by ingredient.  I noticed someone said these were only 2 points on WW.  How did you know?

i made this recipe but IO tweaked it a bit because I didn't like all of the ingredients, and I tend to like spicier food. It is true that when you bake these rolls the skin tends to get hard, however, these are the best things to re-heat! When you re-heat them the skin gets a bit softer and the flavors really develop. I am not sure why but if you find that you don't like them because they are too hard try making them in advance.

My suggestion is to take this basic recipe and add in things that you like. Broccoli slaw is a great addition for its added crunch. Saracha (not sure if my spelling is correct) is also great to add for an added kick!

My roommate and I are really into asian foods. I was a little worried when I seen they weren't traditional. My roommate doesn't get excited about food, but when I made these he told me that if I wouldn't make them for him again he would do it himself (he doesn't cook) We absolutely loved them they were full of flavor and very nice and juicy I took pcs and sent it to several of our friends and family and when they came to try em... Let's just say they are still talkin about them..

I was hoping that since these spring rolls were baked that they wouldn't be so oily.  I guess when you brush them before baking it absorbs too much and holds onto the oil.  These were good, not great.  The ham flavor didn't pop out, it was overpowered by the crab.  The dipping sauce didn't do much for me as well.  I think sweet and sour would have been better.  If you consider doing these, brush them them with egg whites instead of oils, it's what I should have done.
These spring rolls were really, really yummy! I love spring rolls at restaurants but at home when you make them homemade, they taste so much better! Plus, they are a lot better for you! THANKS GUYS!

The g
Green Bay girls made these Baked Sprin rolls on their Monthly get together and we liked them.They are only 2 points for WW. If you brush them with the oil and bake them and dont open the oven only to turn over and brush w oil again they turned out good.We had good crunch.The best part of it was easy and they tasted good.If you want fat then deep fry.

I made a substitution in this recipe since my husband won't eat crab- I substituted chopped cooked chicken. The spring roll interior was delicious and the sauce excellent. I have the same complaint as the first reviewer- baking in the oven made the skins hard, not crispy light and crunchy...although they looked golden brown and scrumptious.  I was easily able to make 20 spring rolls. I used one large tablespoon of filling per roll.  I got this recipe from the Food Network August/September 2009 magazine. I was interested because we are really watching our fat/carb intake and these seemed like a nice substitute...but to save 7 grams of fat per roll by baking is not worth the sacrifice in crispy texture.

I made these for a family game night and was completely disappointed.  The wrappers when baked are hard and almost like they were "nuked".  The ingredients which by themselves have so much flavor i.e. ginger, garlic etc. when mixed together in this recipe are almost non existent.  I doubled the recipe and that just made 14 rolls.  Although I omitted the crab, the rest of the ingredients just didn't mesh well.  There was just something missing..and it wasn't the crab!
